resources.string: Mijikenda are located in the coast of Mombasa Kenya and made up of upto 9 tribes. The nine Ethnic groups that make up the Mijikenda peoples are the Chonyi, Kambe, Duruma, Kauma, Ribe, Rabai, Jibana, and Giriama. They are the northern Mijikenda while the Digo are southern Mijikenda.

The Maasai are an indigenous ethnic group in Africa of semi-nomadic people settled in Kenya and northern Tanzania. Due to their distinct traditions, customs and dress and their residence near the many national game parks of East Africa, the Maasai are among the foremost African ethnic groups and are known internationally because of their links to the national parks and reserves.

The Abagusii is an East African ethnic group that traditionally inhabit Kisii county and Nyamira county of Western Kenya. The Abagusii are also found in other regions of geographical Western Kenya. The Abagusii speak Ekegusii language which is classified together with the Great Lakes Bantu languages

According to the most recent census, there are 2.4 million Somalis in Kenya (out of an overall population of 38.6 million in the country). Somalis have lived in Kenya since before colonial rule. By the early 20th century, Somali-speaking nomads established themselves in what is now northeastern Kenya

Swahili (locally referred to as Kiswahili) is Kenyaâ€™s national language. Swahili originated on the East African coast,as a trade language used by both Arabs and coastal tribes.Popular swahli are wagunya, shebe, shihiri

The Luhya (also known as Abaluyia or Luyia)[2] are a group of 19 distinct Bantu tribes in Kenya that lack a common origin and were politically united in the mid 20th century.[3] They number 6,823,842 people according to the 2019 census, being about 14.35% of Kenya total population of 47.6 million, and are the second-largest ethnic group in Kenya.
